standards: 3.1.1 Read and write numbers up to 10,000 in numerals and words
objectives: Students will be able to read and write numbers up to 10,000 in numerals and words correctly.
activities: Singing number songs up to 10,000
Writing numbers from words to numerals (e.g., 'seven thousand three hundred' → 7300)
Game 'Find the Number' – search for numbers on a large chart
assessment: Worksheet on writing numbers from words
aids: Number word cards (thousands, hundreds, tens, ones)

standards: 3.1.2 Comparing and arranging numbers up to 10,000
objectives: Students will be able to compare two numbers up to 10,000 and arrange them in ascending or descending order.
activities: Arranging number cards in sequence
Game 'The Largest Number' – comparing numbers in groups
Use base ten blocks to show place value
aids: Base ten blocks (thousands, hundreds, tens, ones)

standards: 3.2.1 Adding two numbers up to 10,000 without regrouping
objectives: Students will be able to solve addition number sentences up to 10,000 without regrouping using algorithms or concrete objects.
activities: Using an abacus to add without regrouping
Writing number sentences on the whiteboard
Game 'Quick Add' in pairs

standards: 3.2.2 Adding two numbers up to 10,000 with regrouping
objectives: Students will be able to solve addition number sentences up to 10,000 with regrouping using algorithms or base ten blocks.
activities: Using base ten blocks to show the regrouping process
Activity 'Break the Hundreds/Thousands' – turning 10 tens into 1 hundred
Solving daily problems: 'A company has 4,567 books, buys another 2,893'

standards: 3.3.1 Subtracting two numbers up to 10,000 without regrouping
objectives: Students will be able to solve subtraction number sentences up to 10,000 without regrouping using algorithms or concrete objects.
activities: Using an abacus to subtract without regrouping
Writing number sentences on cards
Game 'Take & Calculate' – take objects and calculate the remainder

standards: 3.3.2 Subtracting two numbers up to 10,000 with regrouping
objectives: Students will be able to solve subtraction number sentences up to 10,000 with regrouping using algorithms or base ten blocks.
activities: Using base ten blocks to show the borrowing process
Activity 'Borrow One' – converting 1 thousand to 10 hundreds
Solving daily problems: 'Mother has 8,000 beans, uses 3,456'

standards: 3.4.1 Solving multiplication of two numbers (two-digit number × one-digit number) without regrouping
objectives: Students will be able to solve multiplication of a two-digit number by a one-digit number without regrouping using algorithms or visual models.
activities: Using grids or boxes for multiplication
Writing number sentences on the board
Game 'Product Matching'

standards: 3.4.2 Solving multiplication of two numbers (two-digit number × one-digit number) with regrouping
objectives: Students will be able to solve multiplication of a two-digit number by a one-digit number with regrouping using algorithms or base ten blocks.
activities: Using base ten blocks to show the regrouping process
Activity 'Multiplication Regroup' – turning 10 ones into 1 ten
Solving daily problems: 'Each bag has 24 marbles, 7 bags = ?'

standards: 3.5.1 Solving division of two numbers (two-digit number ÷ one-digit number) without remainder
objectives: Students will be able to solve division of a two-digit number by a one-digit number without remainder using algorithms or equal sharing models.
activities: Dividing marbles into containers equally
Using picture cards to show division
Game 'Equal Sharing' with toy objects

standards: 3.5.2 Solving division of two numbers (two-digit number ÷ one-digit number) with remainder
objectives: Students will be able to solve division of a two-digit number by a one-digit number with remainder using algorithms or visual models.
activities: Using base ten blocks to show the remainder
Short drama: 'I have 25 candies, shared with 4 friends, how many are left?'
Solving daily problems: '28 books divided among 5 people'

standards: 3.6.1 Understanding proper fractions with numerator 1 and denominators up to 10
objectives: Students will be able to understand and name proper fractions such as ½, ⅓, ¼, ⅕, ..., ¹⁄₁₀ as parts of a whole.
activities: Folding paper into 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10 equal parts
Coloring one part of a divided shape
Using toy pizza to show fractions
assessment: Oral Q&A: 'Is this ¹⁄₈ or ¹⁄₁₀?'

standards: 3.6.2 Writing equivalent fractions for simple proper fractions
objectives: Students will be able to write equivalent fractions for simple proper fractions like ½ = ²⁄₄ = ³⁄₆.
activities: Using paper circles to show equivalent fractions
Matching equivalent fraction cards
Game 'Find the Equivalent Pair' in groups
assessment: Oral assessment: 'What is equivalent to ½?'
aids: Paper circles to cut and compare

standards: 3.7.1 Recognizing and writing decimals up to two decimal places in the context of money
objectives: Students will be able to identify and write decimals up to two decimal places (e.g., RM5.75, RM12.30) in the context of money.
activities: Using replica money to show decimals
Writing item prices in decimal form
Shop game: 'How much is this? Write in RMXX.XX'
assessment: Worksheet on writing prices in decimals
unit: Unit 7: Decimals (Up to two decimal places)

standards: 3.7.2 Recognizing and writing decimals up to two decimal places in the context of measurement
objectives: Students will be able to identify and write decimals up to two decimal places (e.g., 3.50 cm, 1.25 kg) in the context of measurement.
activities: Measuring object lengths and recording in cm (e.g., 12.50 cm)
Weighing light objects and recording in kg (e.g., 0.75 kg)
Game 'Liquid Volume' – pouring water and reading in liters (1.50 L)
assessment: Worksheet on recording measurements in decimals
Oral Q&A: 'How many cm is this?'
unit: Unit 7: Decimals (Up to two decimal places)

standards: 3.8.1 Solving daily problems involving addition and subtraction of money up to RM1,000
objectives: Students will be able to solve daily situations such as buying items and finding change using addition/subtraction of money up to RM1,000.
activities: Drama: 'Buying a book for RM15.50, paying with RM20, what is the change?'
Using money problem story cards
Building number sentences from real situations
aids: Real objects (plastic books, toy water bottles)

standards: 3.8.2 Solving daily problems involving multiplication and division of money up to RM1,000
objectives: Students will be able to solve daily situations such as the price of 5 units or unit price using multiplication/division of money up to RM1,000.
activities: Drama: 'One bread is RM1.50, 4 breads = ?', 'RM10 for 5 apples, how much for one?'
Using money multiplication/division story cards
Game 'Calculate Price' in pairs
assessment: Worksheet on money multiplication/division problem solving

standards: 3.9.1 Performing addition operations involving time units (hours and minutes)
objectives: Students will be able to solve addition number sentences involving hours and minutes (e.g., 2 hours 30 minutes + 1 hour 45 minutes).
activities: Using a large analog clock to show time addition
Game 'Add Time' – adding time in groups
Solving daily problems: 'School starts at 7.30, ends at 12.15'
unit: Unit 9: Time and Duration (Operations Involving Time)
kategori: Addition and Subtraction of Time Units

standards: 3.9.2 Performing subtraction operations involving time units (hours and minutes)
objectives: Students will be able to solve subtraction number sentences involving hours and minutes (e.g., 3 hours 20 minutes – 1 hour 50 minutes).
activities: Using an analog clock to show time subtraction
Game 'Subtract Time' – subtracting time in pairs
Solving daily problems: 'Work starts at 8.00, ends at 4.30'
unit: Unit 9: Time and Duration (Operations Involving Time)
kategori: Addition and Subtraction of Time Units

standards: 3.10.1 Performing addition and subtraction operations involving length (cm, m)
objectives: Students will be able to solve addition and subtraction number sentences involving length in cm and m units.
activities: Measuring two objects, adding/subtracting the results
Using a number line to show length operations
Solving daily problems: 'String A is 2.5 m, String B is 1.75 m, what is the total?'
assessment: Observation of measurement and calculation accuracy
aids: String, wooden boards to be measured
unit: Unit 10: Measurement (Length, Mass, Volume of Liquid - Basic Operations)

standards: 3.10.2 Performing addition and subtraction operations involving mass (g, kg) and volume of liquid (ml, liter)
objectives: Students will be able to solve addition and subtraction number sentences involving mass and volume of liquid in standard units.
activities: Weighing two objects, adding/subtracting their mass
Pouring two liquids, adding/subtracting their volumes
Solving daily problems: 'Water A 500 ml, Water B 350 ml, what is the total?'
assessment: Worksheet on mass and volume operations
unit: Unit 10: Measurement (Length, Mass, Volume of Liquid - Basic Operations)

standards: 3.11.1 Recognizing straight lines and curved lines
objectives: Students will be able to identify and differentiate between straight lines and curved lines in 2D shapes and the environment.
activities: Searching for straight and curved lines in the classroom
Drawing straight and curved lines on paper
Game 'Guess the Line' – teacher shows, student guesses the line type
kategori: Recognizing Lines and Types of Angles

standards: 3.11.2 Recognizing types of angles: right angle, acute angle, obtuse angle
objectives: Students will be able to identify and name types of angles (right, acute, obtuse) using models or real objects.
activities: Using angle models (folded paper) to show angle types
Finding angles in the environment (table, door, book)
Game 'Guess the Angle' – teacher shows an angle, student guesses the name
kategori: Recognizing Lines and Types of Angles

standards: 3.12.1 Calculating the perimeter of squares and rectangles
objectives: Students will be able to calculate the perimeter of squares and rectangles using formulas or measurement methods.
activities: Measuring the sides of quadrilaterals and summing them to find the perimeter
Using base ten blocks to build quadrilaterals and calculate perimeter
Solving daily problems: 'A square garden fence is 5m x 3m, what is the fence length?'
kategori: Calculating Perimeter and Area of Quadrilaterals

standards: 3.12.2 Calculating the area of squares and rectangles
objectives: Students will be able to calculate the area of squares and rectangles using formulas or the grid square method.
activities: Using grid paper to count the area
Building quadrilaterals with base ten blocks and calculating area
Solving daily problems: 'A floor is 4m x 3m, what is its area?'
kategori: Calculating Perimeter and Area of Quadrilaterals

standards: 3.13.1 Constructing bar charts with simple scales (1 unit = 1, 2, 5, 10)
objectives: Students will be able to construct bar charts using collected data and determine suitable scales (1 unit = 1, 2, 5, 10).
activities: Collecting data on the number of books read by friends
Constructing a bar chart with a scale of 1 unit = 2 people
Labeling horizontal and vertical axes with scales
assessment: Observation of construction and scale accuracy

standards: 3.13.2 Interpreting information from bar charts with scales
objectives: Students will be able to read and interpret information from bar charts with scales (e.g., 1 unit = 5 people, how many people like blue?).
activities: Interpreting their own constructed bar charts
Q&A: 'Which has the most?', 'How many like red if 1 unit = 5?'
Game 'Guess the Answer' based on the chart
aids: Examples of bar charts with scales
